name: Bermuda
description: Bermuda, known as the 'Isle of Sunshine', is a British Overseas Territory located in the North Atlantic Ocean. It’s famed for its pink sand beaches, crystal-clear turquoise waters, and unique limestone formations. Bermuda boasts a rich history, vibrant culture, and a thriving tourism industry, attracting visitors from around the globe.

quickFacts.label: Capital
quickFacts.description: The bustling capital city of Bermuda.
quickFacts.detail: Hamilton is a historic port city with a charming waterfront, offering a mix of shops, restaurants, and cultural attractions.

quickFacts.label: GDP
quickFacts.detail: Tourism and international business are the cornerstones of Bermuda's economy.

climateData.title: Bermuda's Climate
climateData.description: Bermuda enjoys a subtropical climate with consistently warm temperatures year-round. The island is influenced by the Gulf Stream, which moderates the temperature and creates a humid atmosphere. Rainfall is relatively consistent throughout the year, with a slightly wetter period in the winter months.

seasonalCharacteristics.name: Summer (June - August)
seasonalCharacteristics.description: Summer brings the warmest temperatures and highest humidity levels. Sunshine is abundant, and the sea is ideal for swimming and water sports.

seasonalCharacteristics.name: Autumn (September - November)
seasonalCharacteristics.description: Autumn sees a gradual decrease in temperature and humidity. Rainfall increases slightly, but the weather remains pleasant for outdoor activities.

seasonalCharacteristics.name: Winter (December - February)
seasonalCharacteristics.description: Winter is the coolest and driest season, with average temperatures ranging from 18-22°C (64-72°F). Bermuda is known for its refreshing Atlantic breezes, which provide relief from the humidity.

seasonalCharacteristics.name: Spring (March - May)
seasonalCharacteristics.description: Spring brings a burst of color as wildflowers bloom across the island. Temperatures gradually increase, and the weather becomes increasingly pleasant.

naturalWonders.name: Horseshoe Bay Beach
naturalWonders.description: Horseshoe Bay Beach is arguably Bermuda's most famous beach, renowned for its pink sand and crystal-clear turquoise waters. The iconic rock formations create a natural horseshoe shape, adding to its dramatic beauty.
naturalWonders.detailedDescription: The pink hue of the sand is due to the presence of crushed coral and shells. The water is exceptionally clear, making it ideal for snorkeling and swimming. The beach also features a historic sandbar that was once used for horse racing.
viewingTips: Arrive early to secure a spot
Explore the sandbar at low tide

naturalWonders.name: Crystal & Fantasy Caves
naturalWonders.description: The Crystal & Fantasy Caves are a network of stunning limestone caves beneath Bermuda, showcasing incredible stalactites, stalagmites, and underground lakes.
naturalWonders.detailedDescription: The Crystal Cave is known for its impressive crystal formations, while the Fantasy Cave features a subterranean lake and a series of chambers adorned with unique geological features. Guided tours are available to explore these subterranean wonders.
viewingTips: Bring a light jacket (cave temperature is cooler)
Listen carefully to the tour guide

naturalWonders.name: Spittal Pond Nature Reserve
naturalWonders.description: Spittal Pond Nature Reserve is a protected area showcasing Bermuda's unique flora and fauna, including a rare population of Bermuda skinks.
naturalWonders.detailedDescription: The reserve encompasses a diverse range of habitats, including wetlands, woodlands, and grasslands. It's a haven for birdwatchers and nature enthusiasts, offering opportunities to observe native wildlife and appreciate Bermuda's natural beauty.
viewingTips: Wear appropriate footwear for walking trails

ecosystemData.title: Bermuda's Ecosystems
ecosystemData.overview: Bermuda’s ecosystems are remarkably diverse considering its small size. The island’s geology, climate, and isolation have fostered unique habitats, including pink sand beaches, limestone caves, and diverse wetlands. Conservation efforts are crucial to protect these fragile environments.
